Technical Assistance Report 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Project Number: 46186-001 
Cluster—Research and Development Technical Assistance (C-RDTA)  
October 2012 
 
 
 
Country Diagnostic Studies in Selected Developing 
Member Countries
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  ERD  –  Economics and Research Department 
  ILO  –  International Labour Organization 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
 
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE CLASSIFICATION 
 
Type  –  Cluster—research and development technical assistance (C-RDTA) 
Targeting  –  General intervention 
classification 
Sector (subsectors)  –  Public sector management (economic and public affairs 
management) 
Themes (subthemes)  –  Economic growth (promoting economic efficiency and enabling 
business environment, widening access to markets and economic 
opportunities); social development (human development); private 
sector development (policy reforms) 
Location impact  –  National (high), regional (high) 
     
 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, "$" refers to US dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  B.N. Lohani, Knowledge Management and Sustainable Development  
Chief Economist  C. Rhee, Economics and Research Department (ERD) 
   
Team leader  C. Park, Assistant Chief Economist, Economic Analysis and Operations 
Support Division, ERD 
Team members  M.R.M. Cham, Senior Economics Officer, ERD 
P.M. Halili, Economics Officer, ERD 
K.Y. Nam, Senior Economist, ERD 
  P. Vandenberg, Economist, ERD 
 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  Commitments under the Paris Declaration require development agencies to work with 
developing  countries  to  improve  development  effectiveness.  As  a  signatory  to  the  Paris 
Declaration, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) has undertaken a number of initiatives to 
improve its assistance and make the national development plans of its developing member 
countries (DMCs) more effective. One such step was to pilot test the diagnostic approach to 
development planning in two ADB-financed technical assistance (TA) projects.1 The proposed 
cluster TA builds on work under the earlier TA by extending the depth and breadth of the 
analytical work and covering a new set of DMCs. A concept paper prepared for the TA was 
approved by the vice-president (knowledge management and sustainable development) on 13 
August 2012.2 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Country diagnostic studies can enhance national development plans and strategies by 
focusing  development  efforts  on  the  most  critical  constraints.  Thorough  diagnostics  were 
emphasized  in  Asian  Development  Fund  XI  discussions  as  the  means  to  improve  ADB 
operations’  quality  at  entry.  However,  DMCs  typically  lack  the  awareness  and/or  capacity 
needed to undertake diagnostics on their own. In particular, capacity for planning and analytical 
capacity is weak in low-income DMCs, which arguably need diagnostics the most to help 
allocate  their  limited  resources  toward  addressing  the  most  critical  constraints  on  their 
economies. In light of this, there is a clear need to help DMCs build their capacity and undertake 
country diagnostic studies. Looking ahead, country diagnostic studies need to be scaled up to 
be able to assist more DMCs. 
 
3.  ADB has introduced diagnostic approaches to development planning to DMCs through 
earlier TA projects (footnote 1)3 with the aim of improving DMCs’ capacity to plan, implement, 
and account for results of their development policies and programs.4 Through these TA projects, 
ADB  has  worked  with  DMC  governments  and  other  development  partners to  undertake  a 
number of country diagnostic studies. These studies incorporated existing frameworks and 
pioneered  approaches  to  diagnose  constraints  on  inclusive  growth  and  environmental 
sustainability—two pillars of ADB’s Strategy 2020.5  
 
4.  To date, ADB has completed country diagnostic studies, for Indonesia, Nepal, Papua 
New Guinea, and the Philippines. Studies for Bhutan, Cambodia, the Maldives, and Thailand 
still continue.6 Findings of these studies have been published through the Critical Development 
                                                
1  ADB. 2007. Technical Assistance for Strengthening Country Diagnosis and Analysis of Binding Development 
Constraints in Selected Developing Member Countries. Manila (TA 6397-REG); ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance 
for Diagnosing Critical Constraints to Growth and Structural Transformation in Selected Developing Member 
Countries. Manila (TA 7686-REG). 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 27 August 2012. 
3  The country diagnostic study for Bhutan is being implemented as a subproject under ADB. 2006. Technical 
Assistance for the Development Partnership Program for South Asia. Manila (TA 6337-REG; financed by the 
Australia–ADB South Asia Development Partnership Facility). 
4  The World Bank, the Inter-American Development Bank, the Department for International Development of the 
United Kingdom, the International Labour Organization (ILO), the Millennium Challenge Corporation, and other 
development partners have widely adopted diagnostic approaches.  
5  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. Manila. 
6  In addition, ADB studied binding constraints on regional cooperation and integration in South Asia, which was a key 
input into formulating the regional cooperation strategy. ADB. 2011. Regional Cooperation Strategy: South Asia, 
2011–2015. Manila.

2   
Constraints series.7 In addition, TA 6397 produced two monographs.8 The studies have been 
widely  appreciated  by  DMC  governments  and  other  stakeholders,  including  development 
partners, for their approach, findings, and recommendations. In terms of impact, the studies 
have contributed to the formulation of national medium-term development plans. For example, 
findings and recommendations from the Philippine study were key inputs into the midterm 
review of the Medium-Term Philippine Development Plan, 2004–2010 and the formulation of the 
Medium-Term Philippine Development Plan, 2011–2016. Similarly, the studies contributed to 
the formulation of current medium-term development plans in Indonesia and Nepal. 
 
5.  DMC governments have found reports from country diagnostic studies to be a useful 
basis for initiating and expanding policy dialogue with development partners, including ADB. For 
example, findings from country diagnostics studies helped governments and ADB  to focus 
country partnership strategies (CPS) for Indonesia, Nepal, and the Philippines on their most 
critical constraints. Further, the governments of Indonesia and the Philippines used reports from 
country diagnostic studies as the bases for dialogue with the Millennium Challenge Corporation 
of the Government of the United States to secure grant assistance.9 Similarly, development 
partners  used  findings  and  recommendations  from  studies  for  Indonesia,  Nepal,  and  the 
Philippines to formulate their own partnership and assistance strategies for these DMCs.10 
 
6.  With this in view, the cluster TA will expand on the work of earlier TA by incorporating 
the lessons learned so far. The key considerations that have guided design of the cluster TA 
include the following: (i) Focusing on process is important when conducting a diagnostic study 
and needs to include ample opportunity for stakeholders to participate in the diagnostic process. 
(ii) Capacity development is more effective when classroom training is augmented with hands-
on training. (iii) Diagnostics should also consider constraints to green growth and knowledge-led 
growth  while  taking  into  account  development  issues  such  as  structural  transformation, 
governance, institutions, and the political economy. (iv) In addition to economy-wide diagnosis, 
diagnostics need to focus on priority sectors in an economy. (v) The dissemination of diagnostic 
approaches needs to be strengthened, especially in countries not selected for diagnostic studies.  
Moreover, learning from the previous experience, the TA adopts a cluster modality, which 
provides an opportunity to cater to the large expressed and potential demand from DMCs for the 
country  diagnostics  over  a  longer  period  of  time  without  tying  down  entire  TA  resource 
requirements at the onset. Cluster modality will also allow for TA to be more responsive to the 
needs  and  timing  of the  DMCs’  planning  cycles  and  ADB’s  CPSs for  these  DMCs,  while 
reducing costs otherwise devoted for processing individual subprojects as standalone TAs. 
 
III.  THE PROPOSED TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
7.  The impact will be the mainstreaming of diagnostic approaches in the development 
planning processes of DMCs. The outcome will be DMCs’ medium-term development plans, 
                                                
7  Various study reports prepared under ADB TA for Strengthening Country Diagnosis and Analysis of Binding 
Development Constraints in Selected Developing Member Countries (footnote 1)..  
8  D. Canlas, M. Khan and J. Zhuang, eds.  2009. Diagnosing the Philippine Economy: Toward Inclusive Growth. 
Manila: Anthem Press and H. Hill, M. Khan; and J. Zhuang, eds. 2012. Diagnosing the Indonesian Economy: 
Toward Inclusive and Green Growth. Manila: Anthem Press.    
9 The Millennium Challenge Corporation approved grant assistance of $434 million for the Philippines in August 2010 
and of $600 million for Indonesia in November 2011. 
10 The ILO and the Department for International Development of the United Kingdom in the case of Nepal, the ILO 
and  Islamic  Development  Bank  in  the  case  of  Indonesia,  and  the  United  States  Agency  for  International 
Development in the case of the Philippines.

3 
poverty reduction strategies, and partnership strategies with development partners addressing 
critical constraints on inclusive economic growth. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
1.  Cluster Technical Assistance 
 
8.  The cluster TA will have four subprojects, each including the introduction of diagnostic 
approaches to development planning and the conduct of country diagnostic studies in 2–4 
DMCs. DMC selection is in consultation with DMC governments and ADB regional departments. 
Ideally, the studies will be timed to inform the formulation and implementation of the selected 
DMCs’ medium-term development plans. The general criteria for selection will be (i) the DMC’s 
weak analytical and planning capacity; (ii) the study’s ability to inform the formulation and/or 
implementation of the DMC’s medium-term development plan; (iii) the DMC’s keen interest in 
the study; and (iv) the likelihood of the study generating a demonstration effect. In consultation 
with ADB regional departments, Bangladesh, Mongolia, Myanmar, Pakistan, Solomon Islands, 
Sri  Lanka,  Tajikistan,  and  Timor-Leste  have  been  identified  for  inclusion  in  the  first  three 
subprojects.11  
 
2.  Subproject 1 
 
9.  Subproject 1 will cover three DMCs—Sri Lanka, Tajikistan, and Timor-Leste—and has 
two main components: (i) conducting country diagnostic studies and (ii) capacity building and 
dissemination. 
 
a.  Conducting Country Diagnostic Studies 
 
10.  Three country studies will diagnose critical constraints on rapid and inclusive economic 
growth with special consideration for green and knowledge-led growth in the selected DMCs 
using (i) growth diagnostic frameworks; (ii) diagnostic frameworks for constraints on reducing 
poverty  and  inequality;  (iii)  diagnostic  frameworks  for  employment  and  labor  markets;  (iv) 
product space analysis; and (v) diagnostic frameworks for the governance, institutional, and 
political economy dimensions of development constraints.  
 
11.  Individual country diagnostic studies will be undertaken over 12–18 months in three 
steps: (i) review development performance and patterns, (ii) conduct an overarching diagnosis 
of constraints on rapid and inclusive economic growth, and (iii) conduct in-depth diagnoses of 
the areas identified by the overarching diagnosis including sector and thematic assessments. 
The studies will be interactive, conducting two or three workshops to inform and consult with 
stakeholders on study approaches, findings, and proposed policy options. Studies will also use 
and build on any recent or ongoing studies or capacity building initiatives by governments, their 
development partners including ADB, and any other institutions to bring out concrete policy 
suggestions to address the constraints.  
 
b.  Capacity Building and Dissemination 
 
12.  The component will create awareness of and capacity in diagnostic approaches in DMCs’ 
governmental planning agencies, ministries, and departments, as well as in research institutions 
and nongovernment organizations. It will include training and advanced training workshops, and 
dissemination workshops in-country and regional.  
 
                                                
11 ADB will obtain a no-objection letter from each selected DMC.

4   
13.  Training workshops will ideally be conducted in the initial stage of an individual study to 
enable participating agencies and individuals to actively contribute to conducting the studies. 
Training workshops spanning 2–3 days will cover the basics of diagnostic frameworks using 
lectures, case studies, and group work. Advanced training workshops will be undertaken at the 
completion of overarching diagnoses and provide training in sector or theme diagnostics. The 
timing of training workshops will be coordinated, where possible, with other capability-building 
initiatives of ADB’s regional departments, especially those related to diagnostics. 
 
14.  Each  of  the  diagnostic  studies  will  include  activities  to  disseminate  diagnostic 
approaches  and  study  findings,  including  workshops  and  the  use  of  print,  broadcast,  and 
internet media. The workshops will target key stakeholders including government agencies, civil 
society, the private sector, academic and research institutions, and development partners. 
 
15.  Moreover, the  subproject  will  organize  a  regional  conference for  DMC  officials  and 
development partners that will provide a venue to showcase ADB’s experiences with diagnostic 
approaches and to learn from the experiences of other development partners.  
 
16.  In addition, the subproject will use country diagnostics study websites to disseminate 
information on diagnostic approaches, as well as the findings and recommendations of the 
studies. It will further reproduce and disseminate existing publications on diagnostic approaches 
and completed country diagnostic studies. 
 
3.  Subsequent Subprojects (Subprojects 2–4)12 
 
17.  Subsequent subprojects will be structured along the lines of subproject 1. Subprojects 
2–4 will also have two components: (i) country diagnostic studies and (ii) capacity building and 
dissemination. The design of subprojects 2–4 is envisaged benefiting from the lessons from 
implementing subproject 1.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
18.  The cluster TA is estimated to cost $6 million equivalent. It will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). Subproject 1 is estimated to cost 
$1,450,000. Details of the cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
19.  ADB, through the Economics and Research Department (ERD), will be the executing 
agency. However, regional departments, resident mission, and subregional offices will be the 
conduits through which ERD coordinates the studies with DMC governments. The TA will be 
implemented in coordination with ADB regional departments and planning agencies and/or the 
relevant ministries of DMCs from December 2012 to December 2018.  
 
20.  The TA will require the services of a number of international and national experts, 
including  development  economists,  sector  specialists,  editors,  and  research  assistants. 
However, the exact requirements for each type of expertise and the length of input will vary 
among DMCs, to be determined after the initial diagnostic of the DMC economy in question is 
completed. For costing purposes, experience from completed and ongoing country diagnostic 
                                                
12 Subsequent sub-projects will be approved in accordance with OM Section D12/OP (2011), which requires that 
approval be through a memorandum to the head of the department or office, which outlining the (i) overall progress 
of the TA cluster to date; (ii) outcome, and intended outputs of the subproject; (iii) cost estimates and budget; (iv) 
implementation arrangements; (v) implementation schedule, (vi) terms of reference of consultants; and (vii) other 
aspects, as appropriate. In addition, the proposal will require a draft DMF and will be subject to consultations with 
departments and/or offices concerned before submission to the head of the department or office for approval.

5 
studies,  and  the  requirement  to  expand  diagnostics  to  cover  additional  dimensions,  have 
indicated consulting services requirements. Requirements for subproject 1 are estimated at 
about 48 person-months of international and 24 person-months of national consulting services. 
In addition, each country diagnostic study in the subproject will require the services of research 
assistants as needed. Outline terms of reference for consultants are in Appendix 3.  
 
21.    Given the limitations outlined above, intermittent nature of assignments, and anticipated 
variety of expertise required, the TA will primarily recruit experts individually, in accordance with 
ADB Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
22.  ADB will procure computers and software in accordance with its Procurement Guidelines 
(2010, as amended from time to time). Procurement will be coordinated with ADB’s Office of 
Information  Systems  and  Technology  and  its  Office  of  Administrative  Services.  Upon  TA 
completion,  procured  equipment  will  be  disposed  of  in  accordance  with  the  project 
administration instruction on administering grant-financed TA projects.13 Disbursements under 
the  TA  will  accord  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement  Handbook  (2010,  as 
amended from time to time). 
 
23.  DMCs for the individual studies will be selected in consultation with DMC governments 
and regional departments. Once an individual study commences, the study team will collaborate 
closely with governmental planning and finance ministries and statistics and other agencies, as 
well  as  with  research  institutions  and  universities.  Each  study  will  include  a  number  of 
consultations to ensure the participation of other stakeholders such as civil society, private 
sector organizations, researchers, and academics. Inputs from governments in selected DMCs 
will include relevant background materials and data. In addition, governments will be expected 
to designate agencies and/or staff as focal points to help coordinate activities with government 
agencies to support the consolidation of inputs from various agencies, finalization of studies, 
and organization of dissemination workshops.  
 
24.  Experience from earlier TA projects has clearly demonstrated usefulness of collaboration 
with development partners, globally reputable research institutions and centers of excellence 
toward building knowledge partnerships and consensus on development directions. Earlier TA 
projects showcased successful collaboration with development partners in conduct of study 
where each collaborating development partner used its own resources to deliver a particular 
aspect of the study based on agreed timelines, and approach that the TA will continue. In 
addition, the TA will partner with in-country development research centers and with global 
centers of excellence such as the International Growth Centre and the John F. Kennedy School 
of  Government.  Various  forms  of  collaboration  will  be  considered  for  such  partnerships, 
including exchange of knowledge, participation of resource persons in training and consultation 
workshops, and contribution of background papers by their researchers toward the studies. The 
TA will shoulder the cost of collaboration, such as resource persons and consultants.  
 
25.  ERD will report on the progress of the TA and of individual studies through established 
project performance management systems.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S RECOMMENDATION  
26.  The President recommends that the Board approve the provision of technical assistance 
not exceeding the equivalent of $6,000,000 on a grant basis for Country Diagnostic Studies in 
Selected Developing Member Countries.

10  Appendix 3 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS FOR SUBPROJECT 1 
 
A.  International Consulting Services 
 
1.  Senior development economists (4 person-months). The economists will advise Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) staff and other experts  on improving and broadening diagnostic 
frameworks. The economists will 
(i)  guide the technical assistance (TA) team in improving and broadening diagnostic 
frameworks to cover regional and sector diagnosis of constraints, 
(ii)  review study reports and suggest improvements to them, and  
(iii)  present experiences of diagnostic approaches in the regional workshop. 
 
2.  Development economists (20 person-months). The economists will typically play lead 
roles in individual diagnostic studies, tasked with an overarching diagnosis of the country, region, 
or sector that will set the stage for the in-depth studies. The economists will 
(i)  facilitate the conduct of a study inception workshop to inform and get feedback 
from key stakeholders, including governments, the private sector, civil society, 
and development partners; 
(ii)  facilitate the formation and functioning of peer groups, drawing membership from 
national  planning  agencies,  academic  and  research  institutions,  other 
development partners, and interested civil society organizations; 
(iii)  review the pattern of growth exhibited and compare it with experiences in similar 
economies within and beyond the region; 
(iv)  dissect economic growth, taking into account production, demand, and supply, 
and compare it with experiences in similar economies within and beyond the 
region; 
(v)  undertake  an  overarching  diagnostic  analysis  of  constraints  to  broad-based 
economic growth, which will identify the topics for in-depth studies; 
(vi)  consolidate  the  findings  of  constraint-specific  studies,  identifying  binding 
constraints and the policy options to address them in a draft country diagnostic 
report; 
(vii)  facilitate  the  conduct  of  the  country  workshop  and  prepare  a  presentation 
summarizing the findings of the country diagnostic report; and 
(viii)  finalize the country diagnostic report by incorporating comments and feedback 
received at the country workshop. 
 
3.  Sector specialists (18 person-months). The specialists will undertake in-depth studies 
of one or two key constraints, which may include poverty and inequality; unbalanced and narrow 
growth; underdevelopment regarding infrastructure, human capital and education, or the finance 
sector;  governance;  macroeconomic  management;  structural  transformation  and  industrial 
policies; health; and the political economy. The specialists will 
(i)  review trends and benchmark them against other countries, regions, and times; 
(ii)  propose a diagnostic framework and finalize it in consultation with stakeholders 
and the study team; 
(iii)  undertake a diagnostic analysis following a systematic framework to identify the 
underlying constraints; 
(iv)  identify the policy options to address the constraints, while keeping in view the 
country context as well as international best practices in these areas; 
(v)  summarize the findings of the studies on the constraint and the policy options to 
address them in a report that will become a section of the larger study report;

Appendix 3  11  
(vi)  coordinate regularly with other colleagues on the evolving findings and provide 
feedback to ensure consistency and complementarity in the final output; and 
(vii)  present the findings of the report in the country workshop. 
 
4.  Editor  (6  person-months).  The  editor  will  oversee  the  publication  of  study  reports, 
coordinating with the development economists and sector specialists to review and finalize 
drafts of overarching and in-depth studies. Under the supervision of ADB staff, the editor will 
(i)  review and edit the draft reports, ensuring that they adhere to ADB style and 
usage, conform to high publication standards, and are properly and promptly 
delivered; 
(ii)  oversee the laying out of the report; 
(iii)  oversee the publication of the report; and 
(iv)  assist in managing the country diagnostics website. 
 
B.  National Consulting Services 
 
5.  Country economists (12 person-months). The economists will undertake or assist in-
depth studies of the critical constraints identified in the overarching analysis. The economists 
will mainly assist the development economists in conducting studies but will also be responsible 
for independent tasks. In undertaking the constraint-specific studies, the economists will 
(i)  assemble  the  relevant  country  and  cross-country  data  sets  and  identify  the 
underlying factors responsible for the critical constraint; 
(ii)  coordinate  regularly  with  colleagues  on  the  evolving  findings  and  provide 
feedback to ensure consistency and complementarity in the final output; 
(iii)  identify relevant policy recommendations for addressing binding constraints; 
(iv)  assist the development economists in presenting the findings of the constraint-
specific studies to the peer group for review and feedback; 
(v)  assist the development economists in summarizing the findings of the constraint-
specific studies in a report, which will become sections of the larger country 
report; and 
(vi)  assist the development economists in presenting the findings of the reports in the 
country workshops. 
 
6.  Country sector specialists (12 person-months). The specialists will undertake or assist 
in the conduct of in-depth sector studies, which may include poverty and inequality; unbalanced 
and narrow growth; underdevelopment regarding infrastructure, human capital and education, or 
the finance sector; governance; macroeconomic management; structural transformation and 
industrial policies; health; and the political economy. In undertaking the in-depth studies, the 
specialists will 
(i)  assemble the relevant country and cross-country data sets; 
(ii)  analyze the data to ascertain and prioritize constraints in the sector; 
(iii)  identify  relevant  policy  recommendations  for  addressing  the  most  critical 
constraints; 
(iv)  assist the development economists in presenting the findings of the constraint-
specific studies to the peer group for review and feedback; 
(v)  assist the development economists in summarizing the findings of the constraint-
specific studies in a report, which will become sections of the larger country 
report; and 
(vi)  assist the development economists in presenting the findings of the reports in the 
country workshops.

12  Appendix 3 
 
7.  Research assistants (as needed). Research assistants will assist staff members of the 
Economics  and  Research  Department  and  the  study  team  in  assembling  and  analyzing 
databases. They will be expected to help manage the study website and mailing list and help 
prepare presentations and reports. Research assistants will assist in 
(i)  the collection and analysis of study data; 
(ii)  updating TA reports, the study website, and the mailing list; and 
(iii)  preparing presentations and reports. 
 
8.  Typesetter/layout  specialist/graphic  designer  (as  needed).  The  typesetter/layout 
specialist/graphic designer will be responsible for designing the text layout, encoding corrections, 
redoing the layout as necessary, formatting graphic elements, typesetting, and preparing for the 
final offset printing of the report and/or manuscript. The specialist will also be responsible for the 
cover and interior design and the execution of layout of the study report and/or manuscript. The 
specialist will 
(i)  refine tables and charts of the main report and highlights using Adobe Illustrator; 
(ii)  refine the layout of main text of the main report and highlights using Adobe 
InDesign; 
(iii)  present a consolidated page proof of main report for final correction (text, tables, 
charts, and cover); 
(iv)  present a consolidated page proof of highlights for final correction (text, tables, 
charts, and cover); 
(v)  deliver PDFs of the main report and highlights for uploading to the regional TA 
website; 
(vi)  encode corrections, if any, on the main report and highlights; and 
(vii)  package final PDFs of the main report and highlights for offset printing.
